NPA and City/Town Search Results|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> [[Area code 323|323]] |website =[http://www.culvercity.org/ culvercity.org] |blank_name =[[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info =06-17568 |blank1_name =[[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info =1652695 |footnotes = }}
'''Culver City''' is a city in western [[Los Angeles County, California]]. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 38,883, up from 38,816 at the 2000 census. It is mostly surrounded by the city of [[Los Angeles]], but also shares a border with [[unincorporated area]]s of Los Angeles County. Culver City's mayor is Christopher Armenta.<ref name="urlCulver City :: City Council Members">{{cite web |url=http://www.culvercity.org/council/council.asp?sec=gov |title=Culver City :: City Council Members |work= |accessdate=}}{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref> Over the years since the city was incorporated, over forty annexations of adjoining areas have occurred. As a result the city now comprises approximately five square miles.
Since the 1920s, Culver City has been a significant center for [[motion picture]] and later television production, in part because it was the home of [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM Studios]]. It was also the headquarters for the [[Hughes Aircraft Company]] from 1932 to 1985. [[National Public Radio]] West and [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] now have headquarters in the city. The [[NFL Network]] studio is also based in Culver City.
== History ==
{{USCensusPop | 1920= 503 | 1930= 5669 | 1940= 8976 | 1950= 19720 | 1960= 32163 | 1970= 34451 | 1980= 38139 | 1990= 38793 | 2000= 38816 | 2010= 38883 | footnote= United States Census Bureau }} === Early History === The area of present day Culver City was the homeland of the [[Tongva people|Tongva-GabrieliÃ±o]] [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]], who held a presence in the region for over 8,000 years.<ref name=Culver>{{cite book|last=Cerra|first=Julie Lugo|title=Culver City|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|year=2004|page=7|isbn=9780738528939}}</ref><ref>[http://www.laokay.com/halac/RanchoLosEncinos.htm laokay: History of Rancho Los Encinos.] accessed 8/20/2010</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/discoveries/2006-03-03-prehistoric-mill_x.htm |title=Prehistoric milling site found in California |publisher=Usatoday.Com |date=2006-03-04 |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref>
The city was founded primarily on the lands of the former [[Rancho La Ballona]], [[Rancho Rincon de los Bueyes]], and [[Rancho La Cienega o Paso de la Tijera]].<ref name=Culver/>
=== Camp Latham === From 1861 to 1862, during the [[American Civil War]], ''Camp Latham'' was established by the [[1st California Infantry]] under Col. [[James H. Carleton]] and the [[1st California Cavalry]] under Lt. Col. [[Benjamin F. Davis]]. Camp Latham was named for California Senator [[Milton S. Latham]] and was the first staging area for the training of Union troops and their operations in [[Southern California]]. It was located on land of the Rancho La Ballona, on the South side of [[Ballona Creek]], near what is now the intersection of Jefferson and Overland Boulevards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~caehmduv/2006Events.htm |title=Camp Latham Marker Unveiling |publisher=Rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militarymuseum.org/FtMoore.html |title=The California State Military Museum, Historic California Posts: Fort Moore (Post at Los Angeles, Fort Hill and including Camp Fitzgerald), reprinted with permission from Colonel Herbert M. Hart, USMC (retired), '''Old Forts of the Far West''', published in 1965 |publisher=Militarymuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militarymuseum.org/CpLatham.html |title=The California State Military Museum, Historic California Posts: Camp Latham |publisher=Militarymuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref> The post was later moved to ''Camp Drum'' later the [[Drum Barracks]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militarymuseum.org/FtMacArthur.html |title=Historic California Posts: Fort MacArthur |publisher=Military Museum |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref>
=== Culver City === [[Harry Culver]]'s first attempt to establish Culver City was in 1913, and the city was [[Municipal corporation|incorporated]] on September 20, 1917. (His first ads read "All roads lead to Culver City" indicating a main transportation route via the city.<ref name=Culver/>)
The first film studio in Culver City was built by [[Thomas H. Ince|Thomas Ince]] in 1918. In the 1920s, [[silent film]] comedy producer [[Hal Roach]] and [[Metro Goldwyn Mayer]] (MGM) built studios there. During [[Prohibition]], [[speakeasies]] and nightclubs such as the [[Cotton Club]] lined [[Washington Boulevard (Los Angeles)|Washington Boulevard]].
[[Image:CulverCity-1913.jpg|thumb||left|The site of Culver City, 1913]]
=== Movie and television production ===
[[Image:MGM-studios-1922.jpg|thumb|left|[[MGM Studios]] (now [[Sony Pictures Studios]]), 1922.]]
Hundreds of movies have been produced on the lots of Culver City's studios: [[Sony Pictures Studios]] (originally MGM Studios), [[Culver Studios]], and the former [[Hal Roach Studios]]. These include ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', ''[[The Thin Man (film)|The Thin Man]]'', ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'', ''[[Citizen Kane]]'', ''[[Rebecca (1940 film)|Rebecca]]'', the ''[[Tarzan]]'' series, and the original ''[[King Kong]]''. More recent films made in Culver City include ''[[Grease (film)|Grease]]'', ''[[Raging Bull]]'', ''[[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial]]'', ''[[City Slickers]]'', ''[[Air Force One (film)|Air Force One]]'', ''[[Wag the Dog]]'', and ''[[Contact (film)|Contact]]''. Television shows made on Culver City sets have included ''[[Las Vegas (TV series)|Las Vegas]]'', ''[[Gunsmoke]]'', ''[[Cougar Town]]'', ''[[Mad About You]]'', ''[[Lassie (1954 TV series)|Lassie]]'', ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]'', ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'', ''[[The Andy Griffith Show]]'', ''[[Jeopardy!]]'', ''[[The Nanny]]'', and the [[Broadcast syndication|syndicated]] version of ''[[Wheel of Fortune (U.S. game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]''.
[[John Travolta]]'s "Stranded at the Drive-In" sequence in ''Grease'' was filmed at the Studio Drive-In on the corner of Jefferson and Sepulveda. It served as a set for many other films, including ''[[Pee-wee's Big Adventure]]''. The theater was closed in 1993 and was demolished in 1998; it is now a housing subdivision featuring large homes on small lots, as well as being home to the [[Kayne-ERAS]] center, a school and community center for the disabled and mentally challenged.
[[Image:Culver City,1920.jpg|thumb|Downtown Culver City, about 1920]] Culver City's streets have been featured in many films and television shows. Since much of the architecture has not changed in decades, particularly in residential areas of town, the nostalgic sitcom ''[[The Wonder Years]]'' set many of its outdoor scenes in the neighborhoods of Culver City. The 1970s show ''[[CHiPs]]'' also featured many chase scenes through the streets. The [[Nicolas Cage]] film ''[[Matchstick Men (film)|Matchstick Men]]'' included scenes made at Veterans Memorial Park, which was also featured in the opening scenes of the sitcom ''[[The Hogan Family]]''.
[[Image:Sonypicturesentertainmentoffices.jpg|thumb|right|Sony Pictures Plaza]] ''[[The Aviator (2004 film)|The Aviator]]'', a film about [[Howard Hughes]], featured several mentions of Culver City in connection with Hughes. The [[Hughes Aircraft|Hughes Aircraft Company plant]] had a Culver City mailing address but was actually in the adjacent [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] neighborhood of [[Westchester, Los Angeles, California|Westchester]] at a site now called [[Playa Vista, Los Angeles, California|Playa Vista]]. Scenes from ''[[Bewitched]]'' (2005) with [[Nicole Kidman]] and [[Will Farrell]] were also filmed in the Culver City streets. The 2005 film, ''[[Fun with Dick and Jane]],'' starring [[Jim Carrey]] was filmed there. The closing aerial sequence of ''[[Get Shorty (film)|Get Shorty]]'' (1995) starring [[John Travolta]] and [[Danny DeVito]] is also filmed in Culver City, at the [[Sony Studios]].
=== Decline of the studios (1960s and 1970s) === {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2009}} In the late 1960s, much of the [[MGM]] back lot acreage (lot 3 and other property on Jefferson Boulevard), and the nearby 28.5 ac (11.5 ha) of the somewhat inaccurately named [[RKO Forty Acres|"back forty"]], once owned by RKO Pictures and later Desilu Productions, were sold by their owners. In 1976, the sets were razed to make way for redevelopment. Today the "back forty" is the southern expansion of the Hayden Industrial Tract, while the MGM property has been converted to a subdivision and a shopping center known as Raintree Plaza.
=== Rebirth of downtown (1990s and 2000s) === [[Image:Culvercenterentrance.jpg|thumb|right|Culver Center]] In the 1990s, Culver City launched a successful revitalization program in which it renovated its downtown as well as several shopping centers in the [[Sepulveda Boulevard]] corridor near [[Fox Hills Mall]]. Around the same time, the relocation of [[Sony]]'s motion picture operations (known as Columbia Pictures)<ref>According to http://www.culvercity.org/cityinfo/history/10202.html, Columbia Pictures was the subsidiary of Sony that moved into the old MGM lot. Retrieved August 3, 2005.</ref> to the former MGM studios at [[Washington Boulevard (Los Angeles)|Washington Boulevard]] and Overland Avenue brought much-needed jobs to the city.
The influx of many art galleries and restaurants to the eastern part of the city, formally designated as the Culver City Art District,<ref>{{cite web|title=Culver City Art District|url=http://www.ccgalleryguide.com/}}</ref> prompted ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2007 to praise the new art scene and call Culver City a "nascent [[Chelsea, Manhattan|Chelsea]]."
== Transportation ==
The first phase of the [[Expo Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Expo line]], a [[light rail]] line from Downtown Los Angeles to a terminal station at the Culver Junction near Venice and Robertson Boulevards in Culver City started in 2006, with an estimated completion date in 2012. The line mostly follows the right-of-way the [[Pacific Electric]] [[Santa Monica Air Line (Pacific Electric)|Santa Monica Air Line]] used. The intent of the [[Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] is that the line eventually be extended westward to [[Santa Monica]], again mostly along the existing right of way.
[[Culver City Bus]] currently operates bus service within Culver City.<ref name="urlmetro.net | Transit Services and Information for Los Angeles County">{{cite web |url=http://www.mta.net/projects_plans/exposition/default.htm |title=metro.net | Transit Services and Information for Los Angeles County |work= |accessdate=}}</ref>
The city is served by the [[Los Angeles International Airport]], which is located about {{convert|7|mi|km}} south of the city.
== Points of interest == [[File:Helmsbakery-6352317857 ebeb0e41ba o.jpg|thumb|Historic Helms Bakery and Beacon Laundry sign on Washington Blvd. in Culver City]] === Businesses === *[[Culver Hotel]]:<ref name="urlWelcome to the Culver Hotel">{{cite web |url=http://www.culverhotel.com |title=Welcome to the Culver Hotel |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> A 1924 landmark pie-slice-shaped hotel in downtown. Many of the cast of ''The Wizard of Oz'' stayed here during filming of the movie in 1939. The hijinks of that period, including the hotel's being taken over by the "Munchkins," were featured in the 1981 movie [[Under the Rainbow]]. Formerly owned by John Wayne, the hotel has housed many stars including [[Clark Gable]], [[Greta Garbo]], [[Joan Crawford]], [[Red Skelton]], [[Buster Keaton]] and [[Ronald Reagan]]. *[[Helms Bakery]],<ref name="urlHelms Bakery District">{{cite web |url=http://www.helmsfurniture.com |title=Helms Bakery District |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> now a center for restaurants, art galleries, the [[Jazz Bakery]] (a jazz club), and furniture sales rooms. *[[Sony Pictures Plaza]]:<ref name="urlSony Pictures">{{cite web |url=http://www.sonypictures.com |title=Sony Pictures |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> This unusual, cantilevered building was featured as the headquarters of Wolfram & Hart, the demonic law firm that was the chief nemesis in the TV Show ''[[Angel (TV series)|Angel]]''. The building is across the street from the main gate of Sony Studios, which is at 10202 W. Washington Boulevard (occupying the former [[MGM]] Studio facilities). {{Rolling Greens}} http://www.rollinggreensnursery.com/This nursery is one of the finds in Culver City. You can walk the hill and pick out your plants ina natural organic setting in the middle of the city
=== Education and research === *[[Star Eco Station]]<ref name="urlecostation.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.ecostation.org |title=ecostation.org |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> is an environmental science and [[wildlife rescue]] center; the STAR ECO Station houses exotic animals that have been abandoned or confiscated and teaches learners of all ages about the environment. At 10101 W. Jefferson Blvd., it offers organized tours. The STAR ECO Station shares its facility with [[STAR Prep Academy]]:<ref name="urlstarprepacademy%org">{{cite web |url=http://www.starprepacademy.org |title=starprepacademy.org |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> a Middle-High School that provides hands on opportunities to work with the animals on site. *[[West Los Angeles College]]<ref name="urlWest Los Angeles College">{{cite web |url=http://www.wlac.edu |title=West Los Angeles College |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> is a two-year [[community college]] within adjacent unincorporated county territory of [[Baldwin Hills, California]]. (''Thomas Guide Los Angeles County,'' page 673.)
=== Local landmarks === [[File:Culvercity-veteransmemorialbuilding-tower-park.jpg|thumb|Veterans Memorial Building with bell tower at Culver Blvd. and Overland Ave.]] *Heritage Fountain at Culver City Hall. *King Fahd Mosque, which can accommodate more than 2,000 worshippers and features a [[minaret]] that is more than {{convert|70|ft|m}} in height.<ref>[http://www.saudiembassy.net/1998News/News/IslDetail.asp?cIndex=1496 "Inauguration of the King Fahd Mosque" from the Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia]</ref>{{Dead link|date=October 2009}} *Veterans Memorial Building at Veterans Park; tower is {{convert|122|ft|m}} high. *[[Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery]] *[[St. Augustine Catholic Church, Culver City|St. Augustine Catholic Church]] *[[Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver City|Holy Cross Cemetery]] is the final resting place to [[Sharon Tate]], [[Bela Lugosi]], and [[Hardcore punk|punk]] legend [[Darby Crash]]. [[Nazli Sabri]], mother of [[Farouk I of Egypt|King Farouk]], was also buried there (she had converted to [[Catholicism]] in 1950).
=== Museums and the arts === *[[The Actors' Gang]]<ref name="url">{{cite web |url=http://www.theactorsgand.com |title=The Actors Gang |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> at the [[Ivy Substation]] (within the Palms district, city of Los Angeles, but on long-term lease to Culver City). *[[Culver City Art District]]:<ref name="urlCULVER CITY ART DISTRICT / CULVER CITY GALLERY GUIDE">{{cite web |url=http://www.ccgalleryguide.com |title=CULVER CITY ART DISTRICT / CULVER CITY GALLERY GUIDE |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> A cluster of more than 30 contemporary art galleries in the vicinity of Washington and La Cienega Boulevards. *[[Culver City Public Theatre]]:<ref name="urlCulver City Public Theatre - Home">{{cite web |url=http://www.ccpt.org |title=Culver City Public Theatre - Home |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> presents an annual summer season of free, outdoor, classical theatre in beautiful Dr. Paul Carlson Memorial Park, at the corner of Motor Avenue and Braddock Drive (near the 405 and 10 Freeways) in Culver City, CA as well as a yearly tradition of presenting theater for young audiences, the Children's Popcorn Theatre. All performances are held during the summer on Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m., with the Childrenâs Popcorn Theater performance at noon. *[[Kirk Douglas Theatre]],<ref name="urlKirk Douglas Theatre | Los Angeles | Center Theatre Group">{{cite web |url=http://www.centertheatregroup.org/theatres/douglas/ |title=Kirk Douglas Theatre | Los Angeles | Center Theatre Group |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> featuring the Center Theater Group *[[The Museum of Jurassic Technology]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjt.org/ |title=The Museum Of Jurassic Technology |publisher=Mjt.org |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref> [[The Actors Circle ]] <ref> {{cite web url [url=http://www.theactorscircle.com] The Actors Circle is and acting studio that provides classes for youth and adults. Located on Sepulveda and Braddock
=== Recreation === *[[Ballona Creek bicycle path]] *[[Culver Boulevard Median bicycle path]], a [[Greenway (landscape)|greenway]] featuring bicycle and pedestrian trailways. *[[Culver Ice Arena]]<ref name="urlCulver Ice Arena - Entry Page">{{cite web |url=http://www.culvericearena.com |title=Culver Ice Arena - Entry Page |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> is a public ice skating rink.
== Neighborhoods == [[Image:Carlson Park Signage.JPG|thumb|[[Dr. Paul Carlson Park]], in the center of the [[Carlson Park, Culver City, California|Carlson Park]] neighborhood]] {{See also|:Category:Neighborhoods in Culver City, California|l1=Category: Neighborhoods in Culver City, California}} Neighborhoods<ref>{{cite web|title=Neighborhoods (map)|url=http://www.culvercity.org/it/maps/Map08_NeighborhoodZone.jpg|work=City of Culver City}}{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref> *[[Beverlywood West]] *[[Blair Hills, Culver City, California|Blair Hills]] *[[Blanco, Culver City, California|Blanco]] *[[Carlson Park, Culver City, California|Carlson Park]] *[[Clarkdale, Culver City, California|Clarkdale]] *[[Culver Crest, Culver City, California|Culver Crest]] *[[Culver West, Culver City, California|Culver West]] *[[Downtown Culver City]] *[[Federal Park, Culver City, California|Federal Park]] *[[Fox Hills, Culver City, California|Fox Hills]] *[[Hayden Tract, Culver City, California|Hayden Tract]] *[[Helms District, Culver City, California|Helms District]] *[[Higuera, Culver City, California|Higuera]] *[[Lucerne, Culver City, California|Lucerne]] *[[Jefferson, Culver City, California|Jefferson]] *[[McLaughlin, Culver City, California|McLaughlin]] *[[McManus, Culver City, California|McManus]] (East Culver City) *[[Park East, Culver City, California|Park East]] *[[Rancho Higuera, Culver City, California|Rancho Higuera]] *[[Studio Estates, Culver City, California|Studio Estates]] *[[Studio Village, Culver City, California|Studio Village]] (Lindberg Park) *[[Sunkist Park, Culver City, California|Sunkist Park]] (El Marino) *[[Telefson Park, Culver City, California|Telefson Park]] *[[Veterans Park, Culver City, California|Veterans Park]] (Park West) *[[Washington Culver, Culver City, California|Veterans Park]]
== Economy == Among the companies based in Culver City are [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] and [[Sizzler]].
According to the City's 2010 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culvercity.org/Government/Finance/~/media/Files/Finance/AnnualReports/CAFR2009_10.ashx |title=City of Culver City CAFR |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref> the top employers in the city are:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! # ! Employer ! # of Employees |- | 1 |[[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] |6,000 |- |2 |Goldrich & Kest Industries |1,100 |- |3 |[[Culver City Unified School District]] |1,084 |- |4 |[[Brotman Medical Center]] |860 |- |5 |City of Culver City |700 |- |6 |Security Industry Specialists |400 |- |7 |[[Target Corporation|Target]] |400 |- |8 |Moldex |300 |- |9 |Karl Storz Endoscopy |300 |- |10 |Kayne Eras Center |300 |}
== Geography == The city is surrounded by the Los Angeles neighborhoods of [[Mar Vista, Los Angeles, California|Mar Vista]], [[West Los Angeles, Los Angeles, California|West Los Angeles]] and [[Palms, California|Palms]] to the north; [[Westchester, Los Angeles, California|Westchester]] to the south; the [[Baldwin Hills, California|Baldwin Hills]] and [[Ladera Heights, California|Ladera Heights]] unincorporated areas to the east; and the L.A. neighborhoods of [[Venice, Los Angeles, California|Venice]] and [[Playa Vista, Los Angeles, California|Playa Vista]] to the west, along with the unincorporated area of [[Marina del Rey, California|Marina Del Rey]].
The two primary [[ZIP codes]] for Culver City are 90230 and 90232. Because [[ZIP codes]] do not necessarily follow city boundaries, a portion of Culver City is in the 90066 [[ZIP code]], which also serves some of the Mar Vista neighborhood of the city of [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]].
The major geographic feature of Culver City is [[Ballona Creek]], which runs northeast to southwest through most of the city before it drains into [[Santa Monica Bay]] in Marina Del Rey.
Culver City is served by the [[Interstate 405 (California)|San Diego]], [[Santa Monica Freeway|Santa Monica]], and [[Marina Freeway|Marina]] [[freeway]]s.
Culver City is at {{Coord|34|0|28|N|118|24|3|W|type:city}} (34.007761, -118.400905).{{GR|1}} According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|5.1|sqmi|km2|1}}, over 99% of which is land.
=== Climate === {{Weather box |location = Culver City, California |single line = Y |Jan high F = 67.3 |Feb high F = 68.6 |Mar high F = 69.3 |Apr high F = 72.6 |May high F = 73.5 |Jun high F = 77.1 |Jul high F = 80.0 |Aug high F = 81.1 |Sep high F = 80.2 |Oct high F = 77.0 |Nov high F = 71.6 |Dec high F = 67.7 |year high F = 73.8 |Jan mean F = 56.7 |Feb mean F = 57.9 |Mar mean F = 59.2 |Apr mean F = 62.3 |May mean F = 64.6 |Jun mean F = 68.0 |Jul mean F = 70.8 |Aug mean F = 71.7 |Sep mean F = 70.8 |Oct mean F = 67.1 |Nov mean F = 61.2 |Dec mean F = 57.0 |year mean F = 63.9 |Jan low F = 46.1 |Feb low F = 47.2 |Mar low F = 49.1 |Apr low F = 52.0 |May low F = 55.7 |Jun low F = 58.8 |Jul low F = 61.5 |Aug low F = 62.2 |Sep low F = 61.3 |Oct low F = 57.2 |Nov low F = 50.8 |Dec low F = 46.3 |year low F = 54.0 |Jan rain inch = 3.19 |Feb rain inch = 3.25 |Mar rain inch = 2.66 |Apr rain inch = 0.58 |May rain inch = 0.26 |Jun rain inch = 0.04 |Jul rain inch = 0.02 |Aug rain inch = 0.07 |Sep rain inch = 0.08 |Oct rain inch = 0.33 |Nov rain inch = 0.94 |Dec rain inch = 1.90 |year rain inch = 13.32 |rain colour = green |Jan rain days = 5.7 |Feb rain days = 5.3 |Mar rain days = 5.8 |Apr rain days = 1.7 |May rain days = 0.7 |Jun rain days = 0.2 |Jul rain days = 0.3 |Aug rain days = 0.2 |Sep rain days = 0.6 |Oct rain days = 1.1 |Nov rain days = 1.9 |Dec rain days = 4.0 |year rain days = 27.5 |unit rain days = 0.01 inch |source 1 = NOAA<ref name= NCDC> {{cite web | url = http://cdo.ncdc.noaa.gov/climatenormals/clim20/ca/042214.pdf | title = Climatography of the United States No. 20 (1971â2000) - Culver City, CA | publisher = [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] | format=PDF | year=2004 | accessdate = 2010-07-25 }}</ref> |date=August 2010}}
== Education == === Primary and secondary schools === Culver City has its own school district, [[Culver City Unified School District]]. It has five elementary schools, a middle school, two high schools (regular and continuation), a Community Day School, an Office of Child Development, and an Adult School. In addition, there is an Independent Study program where students of elementary, middle school, or high school age can make a weekly appointment to drop off and pick up homework, which is to be completed throughout the week.
[[STAR Prep Academy]], a private middle and high school, was established in 2004 and shares its campus with the STAR ECO Station, an exotic wildlife rescue center. It is one of the few schools in the United States in which students have the unique opportunity to work with exotic and endangered animals on a daily basis as part of their school-day curriculum.<ref name="urlstarprepacademy%org" />
=== Colleges and universities === [[West Los Angeles College]], located in an [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] section of Los Angeles County adjacent to Culver City,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaea.culvercity.org/imf/imf.jsp?site=GenCity |title=Culver City General Map |publisher=Gaea.culvercity.org |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref> is part of the [[Los Angeles Community College District]]. [[Antioch University Los Angeles]] is also located in Culver City, off Slauson Avenue. Additionally, Culver City is home to [[Pepperdine University]]'s Graduate School of Education and Psychology and Graziadio School of Business and Management, located in the [[Howard Hughes Center]].
=== Other === The Los Angeles County Probation Department's Training Academy is housed on the campus of West L.A. College.
Culver City is the location for the Los Angeles area campus of the [[Gemological Institute of America]] as well as [[Culver Beauty College]] and the [[Biofeedback Institute of Los Angeles]].
== Demographics == === 2010 === The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref>{{USCensus-2010CA}}</ref> reported that Culver City had a population of 38,883. The [[population density]] was 7,566.0 people per square mile (2,921.2/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Culver City was 23,450 (60.3%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 3,694 (9.5%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 191 (0.5%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 5,742 (14.8%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 81 (0.2%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 3,364 (8.7%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 2,361 (6.1%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 9,025 persons (23.2%).
The Census reported that 38,572 people (99.2% of the population) lived in households, 84 (0.2%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 227 (0.6%) were institutionalized.
There were 16,779 households, out of which 4,499 (26.8%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 6,826 (40.7%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 1,882 (11.2%) had a female householder with no husband present, 636 (3.8%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 922 (5.5%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 157 (0.9%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 5,649 households (33.7%) were made up of individuals and 1,956 (11.7%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.30. There were 9,344 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (55.7% of all households); the average family size was 3.01.
The population was spread out with 7,312 people (18.8%) under the age of 18, 2,711 people (7.0%) aged 18 to 24, 12,098 people (31.1%) aged 25 to 44, 10,956 people (28.2%) aged 45 to 64, and 5,806 people (14.9%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 40.5 years. For every 100 females there were 89.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 85.6 males.
There were 17,491 housing units at an average density of 3,403.5 per square mile (1,314.1/kmÂ²), of which 9,111 (54.3%) were owner-occupied, and 7,668 (45.7%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 0.7%; the rental vacancy rate was 4.1%. 21,549 people (55.4% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 17,023 people (43.8%) lived in rental housing units.
=== 2000 === As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 38,816 people, 16,611 households, and 9,518 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 7,589.8 inhabitants per square mile (2,932.9/kmÂ²). There were 17,130 housing units at an average density of 1,294.3/km Â² (3,349.5/miÂ²). The racial makeup of the city was 59.24% [[Race (United States Census)|White]], 11.96% [[Race (United States Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.71% [[Race (United States Census)|Native American]], 12.02% [[Race (United States Census)|Asian]], 0.21% [[Race (United States Census)|Pacific Islander]], 10.16% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 5.69% from two or more races. 23.70% of the population were [[Hispanics in the United States|Hispanic]] or [[Race (United States Census)|Latino]] of any race.
There were 16,611 households out of which 26.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 40.8% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 12.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 42.7% were non-families. 34.5% of all households were made up of individuals and 9.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.31 and the average family size was 3.02.
In the city the population was spread out with 20.9% under the age of 18, 6.6% from 18 to 24, 33.3% from 25 to 44, 25.3% from 45 to 64, and 13.9% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females there were 87.5 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 82.7 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $51,792, and the median income for a family was $61,451 (these figures had risen to $65,525 and $82,582 as of a 2007 estimate<ref>{{cite web|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ACSSAFFFacts?_event=Search&geo_id=16000US0616000&_geoContext=01000US|04000US06|16000US0616000&_county=culver+city&_cityTown=culver+city&_state=04000US06 |title=Culver City city, California - Fact Sheet - American FactFinder |publisher=Factfinder.census.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref>). Males had a median income of $46,683 versus $41,478 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $29,025. About 5.5% of families and 8.6% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 12.1% of those under age 18 and 5.1% of those age 65 or over.
== Government and infrastructure == In [[Los Angeles County]], Culver City is located in the 2nd Supervisorial District, currently represented by [[Mark Ridley-Thomas]]. In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Culver City is located in the 26th [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Democrat [[Curren D. Price, Jr.]], and in the 47th [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] District, represented by Democrat [[Holly J. Mitchell]]. Federally, Culver City is located in [[California's 33rd congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of D +36<ref>{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}}</ref> and is represented by Democrat [[Karen Bass]].
The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] SPA 5 West Area Health Office serves Culver City.<ref>"[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phcommon/public/aboutus/aboutdisplay.cfm?ou=ph&prog=chs&unit=spa5 About Us]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 18, 2010.</ref> The department operates the Simms/Mann Health and Wellness Center in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]], serving Culver City.<ref>"[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/santamonica.pdf Simms/Mann Health and Wellness Center]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 27, 2010.</ref>
The [[United States Postal Service]] operates the Culver City Post Office at 11111 Jefferson Boulevard and the Gateway Post Office at 9942 Culver Boulevard.<ref>"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/51250?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Culver+City Post Office Location - CULVER CITY]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref><ref>"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/15849?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Culver+City Post Office Location - GATEWAY]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref>
Culver City is served by its own police force, the [[Culver City Police Department]], located at 4040 Duquesne Avenue.<ref>"[http://www.culvercity.org/Government/PublicSafety/Police.aspx Culver City Police Department]."</ref>
